segment.source: Service an Applied Windows Image
segment.target: Service an Applied Windows Image

segment.source: Service an Applied Windows Image
segment.target: Service an Applied Windows Image

segment.source: Service an Applied Windows Image
segment.target: Service an Applied Windows Image

segment.source: Windows® image (.wim) files contain one or more volume images for a Windows® operating system.
segment.target: Windows® image (.wim) files contain one or more volume images for a Windows® operating system.

segment.source: A volume image represents the captured volume or partition of a Windows operating system.
segment.target: A volume image represents the captured volume or partition of a Windows operating system.

segment.source: If you have to re-capture a Windows image, or export a copy of a specific .wim file to another .wim file, or append a volume image to an existing .wim file, you can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to apply the image, and then service the image when it is applied.
segment.target: If you have to re-capture a Windows image, or export a copy of a specific .wim file to another .wim file, or append a volume image to an existing .wim file, you can use the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool to apply the image, and then service the image when it is applied.

segment.source: Then you can boot to audit mode to resolve pending online actions, and add applications or make additional customizations.
segment.target: Then you can boot to audit mode to resolve pending online actions, and add applications or make additional customizations.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: To complete the walkthrough, you need the following:
segment.target: To complete the walkthrough, you need the following:

segment.source: A computer that has the latest version of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) tools installed on it.
segment.target: A computer that has the latest version of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) tools installed on it.

segment.source: Before you can apply a Windows image to a hard disk drive partition, you must create the hard disk partitions on the destination computer.
segment.target: Before you can apply a Windows image to a hard disk drive partition, you must create the hard disk partitions on the destination computer.

segment.source: For more information, see Hard Drives and Partitions.
segment.target: For more information, see Hard Drives and Partitions.

segment.source: You must have the master Windows image (.wim file) and the language packs, drivers, or other packages available in an available location to add them to the Windows image.
segment.target: You must have the master Windows image (.wim file) and the language packs, drivers, or other packages available in an available location to add them to the Windows image.

segment.source: A bootable Windows PE disk.
segment.target: A bootable Windows PE disk.

segment.source: For more information, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive You can also apply the image from another operating system on the same computer, such as Windows 8 or Windows 7 with the latest ADK tools installed.
segment.target: For more information, see WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive You can also apply the image from another operating system on the same computer, such as Windows 8 or Windows 7 with the latest ADK tools installed.

segment.source: Procedures
segment.target: Procedures

segment.source: Step 1: Boot to Windows PE and Apply the Windows Image
segment.target: Step 1: Boot to Windows PE and Apply the Windows Image

segment.source: In this step, you boot to Windows PE and apply a Windows image so that it can be serviced offline.
segment.target: In this step, you boot to Windows PE and apply a Windows image so that it can be serviced offline.

segment.source: To apply an image
segment.target: To apply an image

segment.source: On the destination computer, boot to Windows PE.
segment.target: On the destination computer, boot to Windows PE.

segment.source: For more information, see WinPE for Windows 10.
segment.target: For more information, see WinPE for Windows 10.

segment.source: At a command prompt, apply the master Windows image using DISM.
segment.target: At a command prompt, apply the master Windows image using DISM.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: For more information about DISM commands, see DISM Image Management Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about DISM commands, see DISM Image Management Command-Line Options.

segment.source: Step 2: Add Packages to the Windows Image
segment.target: Step 2: Add Packages to the Windows Image

segment.source: Use DISM to add packages to your master Windows image.
segment.target: Use DISM to add packages to your master Windows image.

segment.source: To add a package to the image
segment.target: To add a package to the image

segment.source: At a command prompt, run DISM with the /Add-Package option and point to the .cab or .msu package that you want to add to the Windows image.
segment.target: At a command prompt, run DISM with the /Add-Package option and point to the .cab or .msu package that you want to add to the Windows image.

segment.source: Multiple packages can be added on one command line.
segment.target: Multiple packages can be added on one command line.

segment.source: For example, type the following command to add multiple packages:
segment.target: For example, type the following command to add multiple packages:

segment.source: For more information about these DISM command-line options, see DISM Operating System Package Servicing Command-Line Options.
segment.target: For more information about these DISM command-line options, see DISM Operating System Package Servicing Command-Line Options.

segment.source: You can also use DISM command-line options on an applied Windows image to add drivers, add language packs, change to a higher edition of Windows, or apply an unattended answer file.
segment.target: You can also use DISM command-line options on an applied Windows image to add drivers, add language packs, change to a higher edition of Windows, or apply an unattended answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see:
segment.target: For more information, see:

segment.source: DISM Driver Servicing Command-Line Options
segment.target: DISM Driver Servicing Command-Line Options

segment.source: DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options
segment.target: DISM Languages and International Servicing Command-Line Options

segment.source: DISM Windows Edition-Servicing Command-Line Options
segment.target: DISM Windows Edition-Servicing Command-Line Options

segment.source: DISM Unattended Servicing Command-Line Options
segment.target: DISM Unattended Servicing Command-Line Options

segment.source: Check the log file to verify that the package was successfully added.
segment.target: Check the log file to verify that the package was successfully added.

segment.source: Some packages and drivers that were added or removed could be in a pending state.
segment.target: Some packages and drivers that were added or removed could be in a pending state.

segment.source: This is usually because a restart is required to complete the action.
segment.target: This is usually because a restart is required to complete the action.

segment.source: Booting the image to audit mode will satisfy the restart requirement, and let you add applications and make additional customizations.
segment.target: Booting the image to audit mode will satisfy the restart requirement, and let you add applications and make additional customizations.

segment.source: For more information, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.
segment.target: For more information, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.

segment.source: Next Step
segment.target: Next Step

segment.source: This walkthrough illustrates basic offline servicing of an applied Windows image in Windows PE.
segment.target: This walkthrough illustrates basic offline servicing of an applied Windows image in Windows PE.

segment.source: When you complete this process, the packages are added to the Windows image.
segment.target: When you complete this process, the packages are added to the Windows image.

segment.source: You can now either run to remove machine-specific customizations and recapture the image for later deployment, or run to keep the specialized customizations and ship this computer.
segment.target: You can now either run to remove machine-specific customizations and recapture the image for later deployment, or run to keep the specialized customizations and ship this computer.

segment.source: Using the option will ensure that the computer starts in Out-of-Box Experience (OOBE) mode the next time that it is booted.
segment.target: Using the option will ensure that the computer starts in Out-of-Box Experience (OOBE) mode the next time that it is booted.

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview.
